title: Enhancing waste resource efficiency: circular economy for sustainability and energy conversion - Frontiers
summary: The article discusses the optimization of waste resource efficiency within the Circular Economy (CE) framework, emphasizing the importance of waste management and energy conversion methods in Poland. It analyzes the core principles of CE across product life cycles and highlights strategies for sustainable waste management, including the Orli Staw municipal waste treatment facility. The research underscores a dual perspective on waste as both a valuable raw material and a potential energy resource, advocating for practices that enhance urban energy self-sufficiency. Key findings indicate practical insights for integrating waste management strategies into sustainable urban development.
green_innovation: TRUE: This is green innovation because it focuses on waste management, energy conversion methods, and optimizing resource efficiency, contributing to environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: TRUE: This is a business innovation as it introduces improved processes in waste treatment facilities that significantly differ from previous practices, enhancing efficiency and profitability.
green_product: FALSE: The article does not specifically identify a good or service that meets the criteria of a green product; it primarily focuses on processes and strategies.
green_process: TRUE: This is a green process because it involves methods in waste management and biogas production that minimize environmental impacts and promote sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 562212 - Solid Waste Landfill; 562213 - Solid Waste Combustors and Incinerators; 562910 - Remediation Services; 541620 - Environmental Consulting Services
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not appear to be an example of greenwashing as it provides substantive insights and practices aimed at environmental sustainability rather than misleading claims about environmental benefits.

title: Supply chain sustainability: Teaming up with suppliers to protect people and the planet - Philips
summary: Philips has implemented a Supplier Sustainability Performance (SSP) program to drive continuous improvement in the sustainability of its supply chain, moving beyond traditional auditing methods. The program focuses on proactive, structural improvements in social and environmental performance by addressing root causes of issues. Philips provides expertise to suppliers, aiming to foster mature and sustainable practices while ensuring safe working environments and responsible sourcing. The approach emphasizes long-term relationships and collaborative problem-solving.
green_innovation: TRUE. The SSP program promotes sustainable and environmentally sound practices within the supply chain, focusing on continuous improvement and reducing negative impacts on workers and the environment.
business_innovation: TRUE. The SSP program represents a new and improved approach to supplier management that significantly differs from traditional auditing methods, which were insufficient in driving sustainable improvements.
green_product: FALSE. The article does not discuss a specific good or service that meets the criteria of a green product.
green_process: TRUE. The SSP program refers to a process that minimizes environmental impacts and promotes sustainability through continuous improvement and proactive management.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 334310 - Audio and Video Equipment Manufacturing; 423450 - Medical, Dental, and Hospital Equipment and Supplies Merchant Wholesalers; 541611 - Administrative Management and General Management Consulting Services; 541612 - Human Resources Consulting Services.
greenwashing: FALSE. The article does not exhibit characteristics of greenwashing, as it describes genuine efforts by Philips to improve sustainability in its supply chain rather than making misleading claims about environmental benefits.

title: A-Gas authorised as R448A/R449A reclaimer - Cooling Post
summary: A-Gas has been authorized by Chemours to reclaim lower GWP refrigerants R448A and R449A in the UK and Europe. These refrigerants, developed by Chemours and Honeywell, serve as replacements for more harmful refrigerants. The collaboration aims to maximize resource efficiency and reduce emissions through safe recovery and reclamation processes. A-Gas offers comprehensive lifecycle management for refrigerants, enhancing sustainability in their use.
green_innovation: TRUE: This is green innovation because it promotes the recycling and reclamation of refrigerants, reducing waste and emissions, and supporting environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: TRUE: This is a business innovation as it involves a new collaboration between A-Gas and Chemours to provide a service for recycling and reclaiming refrigerants, which is a significant improvement over previous methods.
green_product: FALSE: The article does not mention a specific product that meets the green product definition; it discusses refrigerants and the service of recycling them rather than a distinct product itself.
green_process: TRUE: This is a green process as it involves methods for the safe recovery, reclaim, and reuse of refrigerants, minimizing environmental impacts and promoting sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 325120 - Industrial Gas Manufacturing; 562910 - Remediation Services; 423730 - Warm Air Heating and Air-Conditioning Equipment and Supplies Merchant Wholesalers; 541620 - Environmental Consulting Services
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not suggest any misleading claims about the environmental benefits of the refrigerants; instead, it discusses legitimate partnerships aimed at improving sustainability.

title: Study stirs controversy over the benefits of biodegradable plastics - The National
summary: A controversial study suggests that compostable plastic bags may release more toxins than conventional plastic bags during breakdown, raising doubts about their environmental benefits. Critics, including European Bioplastics, argue the study's methodology is flawed and does not accurately represent real-world conditions. The article explores the debate over biodegradable plastics, their degradation processes, and the need for better understanding of their environmental impact. Concerns are also raised about biodegradable plastics diverting attention from reducing plastic usage altogether.
green_innovation: TRUE - The article discusses biodegradable plastics, which aim to reduce plastic waste and environmental harm, aligning with the principles of green innovation.
business_innovation: TRUE - The study and discussion of biodegradable plastics represent a significant development in product offerings within the market, qualifying as business innovation.
green_product: TRUE - Biodegradable plastics are designed to significantly reduce environmental impact, thus meeting the definition of a green product.
green_process: FALSE - The article does not specifically describe a process that minimizes environmental impacts in manufacturing or production.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 325211 - Plastics Material and Resins Manufacturing, 326140 - Polystyrene Foam Product Manufacturing, 326111 - Plastics Bag and Pouch Manufacturing, 424130 - Industrial Supplies Wholesalers
greenwashing: FALSE - The article focuses on a scientific study and the critical viewpoints surrounding biodegradable plastics rather than making misleading claims about their environmental benefits.

title: From gadget to garbage - newagebd.net
summary: The article discusses the escalating issue of electronic waste (e-waste) in Bangladesh, which generates approximately 2.7 million tonnes annually, expected to double by 2030. Highlighting the environmental and health dangers posed by e-waste, it calls for a comprehensive approach to e-waste management, emphasizing the need for better legislation, recycling facilities, consumer education, and collaboration among stakeholders. The article outlines the resource recovery potential from e-waste and advocates for a circular economy to minimize environmental impacts. Overall, it underscores that effective e-waste management is crucial for sustainability and aligns with global environmental goals.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the article discusses methods and approaches to manage e-waste, which aims to reduce negative environmental impacts and promote sustainability.
business_innovation: FALSE, because the article does not describe a specific new or improved product or business process introduced to the market; it focuses primarily on the challenges and potential solutions regarding e-waste management.
green_product: FALSE, because the article does not mention a specific good or service that fits the definition of a green product.
green_process: TRUE, because the article describes processes related to e-waste management that minimize environmental impact and promote sustainability through recycling and recovery of valuable materials.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 334111 - Electronic Computer Manufacturing, 423620 - Electrical and Electronic Appliance, Television, and Radio Set Merchant Wholesalers, 562920 - Materials Recovery Facilities, 923120 - Administration of Urban Planning and Community and Rural Development.
greenwashing: FALSE, because the article does not present misleading claims about e-waste management practices; instead, it accurately identifies the challenges and proposes concrete solutions for addressing the e-waste issue.

title: Why Tissue Paper is THE SMART CHOICE for a Sustainable World - Mixerplanet
summary: The article emphasizes the environmental benefits of tissue paper, including its renewable and biodegradable properties along with sustainable forestry practices. It discusses the industry's commitment to the EU Circular Economy Action Plan and highlights innovations aimed at reducing waste and promoting resource efficiency. It also outlines the industry's efforts in sustainable production, recycling, and customer education regarding proper waste disposal. Overall, tissue paper products are positioned as essential for health and hygiene while contributing to environmental sustainability.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the article describes innovations in the tissue paper industry that promote sustainability, reduce waste, and utilize renewable resources, aligning with environmental goals.
business_innovation: TRUE, as the article discusses new and improved processes and products in the tissue paper industry that significantly differ from previous practices and have been introduced to the market.
green_product: TRUE, since tissue paper is presented as a product designed to reduce environmental impact through its renewable and biodegradable nature, supporting recycling and sustainable consumption.
green_process: TRUE, because the article outlines manufacturing processes in the tissue paper industry that minimize environmental impact, such as reducing water consumption and using energy-efficient technologies.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 322121 - Paper (except Newsprint) Mills; 321113 - Softwood Veneer and Plywood Manufacturing; 322130 - Paperboard Mills; 322299 - All Other Converted Paper Product Manufacturing.
greenwashing: FALSE, as the article provides substantive evidence and specific initiatives supporting the environmental claims made about tissue paper products, indicating genuine commitment to sustainability rather than misleading marketing.

title: The important role played by plant growth regulators - Turf & Rec
summary: The article discusses the environmental benefits of using plant growth regulators (PGRs) in turfgrass management, highlighting their roles in reducing mowing frequency, improving stress tolerance, and enhancing nitrogen use efficiency. Various PGRs are analyzed for their impact on sustainability in turf management, particularly how they promote resource conservation and operational efficiency while minimizing environmental impacts. The article promotes the use of scientific research to support the sustainable application of PGRs for improved turf quality. Ultimately, it advocates for the development of new sustainable products in the turfgrass management sector.
green_innovation: TRUE. This innovation contributes to environmental sustainability by reducing resource consumption, conserving water, and minimizing nitrogen inputs, demonstrating a clear focus on decreasing the negative environmental impacts of turfgrass management.
business_innovation: TRUE. The introduction of plant growth regulators (PGRs) as new tools for turfgrass management represents an improved business process that significantly differs from traditional methods, thus qualifying as business innovation.
green_product: FALSE. While PGRs are used in managing turf, they themselves are not categorized as green products since they do not meet the definition of being designed, manufactured, and used specifically to reduce environmental impact throughout their life cycle.
green_process: TRUE. The application of PGRs in turfgrass management exemplifies a green process by minimizing environmental impacts through reduced mowing frequency, lower water use, and improved nutrient management.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 111421 - Nursery and Tree Production; 115112 - Soil Preparation, Planting, and Cultivating; 811310 - Commercial and Industrial Machinery and Equipment (except Automotive and Electronic) Repair and Maintenance; 561730 - Landscaping Services
greenwashing: FALSE. The article does not exhibit greenwashing; instead, it provides substantiated claims about the environmental benefits of using PGRs supported by scientific research, promoting genuine sustainable practices in turfgrass management.
